moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6: Of all the defenses I play against, I think I like this one least.  Although the potential for play with 3. Bb4 is there, it never leads to a clean game, merely a muck.
moves.3. Nc3 c6 4. d4 Qe7 5. Bc4 h6 6. O-O g6: This gave me an idea: I was playing a pawn-roller.  Usually the best way for me to play these games is let the pawns come until they weaken themselves.
moves.7. b3: Why?  A newly found fondness for the fiancetto, I suppose.  There's not really a good tactical reason, 7. Be3 is better.
moves.7... Bg7 8. Re1 b5 9. Bd3 Nf6 10. Bb2: Preparing to assault the Queen's pawns; the diagonal must hold.
moves.10... O-O 11. d5: If 11. ... cxd5 12. Nxd5 will eventually anchor Black's center with the KP.  If 11. ... c4 12. Bxb5 wins a pawn and a huge bishop threat.
moves.18. Nd2: Looking to capitalize on his progress, White tries to trade off the Queens.
Black has won back the Rook, and will win a pawn back as well.
moves.28... Rxa2 29. Rb1 h5 30. Ba3: White forgot Qc3 first, and should have then moved Ra1.  Another stupid mistake.
That was ugly.  White gives up.  Lesson: don't stop thinking just because you have a huge advantage.
